item.description:
Underworld Couriers is a pick-up and deliver game with a twist.

Players are couriers contracted to carry illicit goods around a map of the globe.

Using a timeline, players must plan the most effective mode of travel between pick-up point and delivery location (air, road, rail or ship). Each of these types of transport takes travels at a different speed, costs various amounts and entails certain risks (passing through customs).

Successfully completing a delivery will earn the player Notoriety and money. But be careful not to get caught or you risk a stint in jail.

The most Notorious player at the end of the game is the winner.

Take the fight to the Pacific!

Frontline is a tactical WWII ground combat card game for 1 to 4 players. This second game in the series covers small unit action during the battle for Guadalcanal.

Each player commands a squad of 4 to 10 American or Japanese soldiers and vehicles. Each card represents one soldier or vehicle. Each unit has inherent actions each turn including moving and attacking with different modes of fire. An action card deck enhances basic actions, and provides units with spur of the moment options.

The game uses counters to illustrate vital game information such as wounds, range, ammo, command, and morale. The range system is easy to use and simulates the movement of forces on the battlefield.

Frontline can also be played solitaire using the enemy Tactic cards. These cards give general, specific, and conditional orders to the enemy troops based on the current battlefield situation.

You can create battles by purchasing your starting forces, playing pre-made scenarios, or using the balanced randomized engagement rules.

Scheduled Components:
165 Full color cards (63mm x 88mm)
1 Full color counter sheet
Rulebook (Full Color)

Complexity:
Low to Moderate
Players move around the board with the help of spinner to grab money bags. Player with the most money bags wins in the end of the game.

Welcome to Crashbot Derby! In this board game, you play as one of 8 superpowered robots competing in the ultimate mechanized demolition derby! Attack your enemies with wild weapons, treacherous traps, or just by crashing into them! Don’t get sidetracked, though: the object is to cross the finish line first!

Gameplay

You're in a race with up to 5 other players; your goal is to complete 3 laps (enter a checkpoint space 6 times, essentially) first. Along the way, you may step on special spaces that will give you sparks (the "currency" of this game), cards, or allow you to activate your unique Robopower!

On your turn you may do these things:
- roll a 6-sided die 2 times 
- spend sparks if you have them
- play cards if you have them
You can do these in any order. You can spend sparks 
or play cards between die rolls.

Of course, racing is only part of it: the other part is fighting! You can attack your opponents with the cards in your hands , which usually represent a gizmo you can use offensively. You can also spend 3 red sparks to shoot opponents... and of course, as the name implies, you can crash into them!

Players are never eliminated from the game, they continue racing until a winner crosses the finish line!

Players spin the spinner and may follow 2 different paths. Longer path through Regent Park and shorter but harder path what passes Cruella de Vil's gates. There are special spaces where player advance additional spaces if he stops there.
Player must spin exact number to put him on finish and win.

Players try to get their balls to holes using a unique pendulum mechanism to strike the cue ball.
Who strikes all of his balls to holes first wins the game.

name.value: Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs

item.description:
45 cards, in four suits - Diamonds, Stars, Circles and Squares. The game is inspired by the playing card game of Hearts or Black Maria. This is a trick taking game where you lose points if you 'collect' a trick containg Stars or the 3 Witch Cards. When one player has a score of 200 points against him, the game ends, and the player with the lowest score wins.

This was the first card game published by Castell. Belisha, Progress, and Speed were all part of this new range.

In 1951, the game was reissued with slightly different rules and new card illustrations, and a new name:
Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs

name.value: VeggieTales: The Madame Blueberry Hunt 4 Happiness Card Game

item.description:
The dealer shuffles the orange stuff-cards and spreads them all face down. Place the blue stuff-cards face down in a deck to the side of Madame Blueberry's pile of orange cards. The youngest player starts.

The first player draws a card from the orange pile and places it face up in front of him/her.
If a Thankful card with a heart is drawn, discard all of your stuff cards and the next player goes.
When an orange stuff card is drawn, put it in front of you. Even if it's a card you don't need.
If a salesman card is drawn with a $ sign, the player must draw 2 blue stuff cards. Place those stuff cards in front of you and discard the salesman card.
If the Madame Blueberry card is drawn, keep on drawing until you get a Thankful card. Put back all the other stuff cards, including the ones you already had.

The first player who gets four thankful cards to make a happy heart wins the game.

A card game with 44 cards, 22 representing the First Division and 22 representing the Second Division.
Players try to score goals by playing cards which have number on them. You add up the cards played and if they total 120 or more, a goal is scored (you have covered the distance from your goalk to your opponent's goal). There are special cards that provide interaction - Goalkeepers, Penalty Cards and Obstruction Cards.

A movie-related game but not Disney this time. This game made use of scenes from the cartoon film by Max Fleischer at Paramount studios. Published anonymously by Pepys because they didn't want to risk losing their good-will with Disney.
44 cards, each with an illustration and a word. Players must add a card to the centre of the table in their turn. Only the word on the card added is important. It must make sense and contribute to a proper sentence. When the 7th or more card is added and a sentence is finished, the player playing the last card to the sentence takes the 'trick'.

44 cards, in sets of 6 racehorses. There are also a number of special cards (Objection to Winner, that sort of thing). When a player is dealt his hand of three cards at the start, he must place a secret bet on which horse will win the race. These bets are written down and the paper folded. A horse wins the race when one player has collected a full set of that horse's cards.

A very unusual offering from Pepys. They were commisioned by the Observer Corps as an aid to help sevicemen to recognise different aircraft. There were two sets printed, one with 52 cards and a joker with silhouettes of aircraft and the cards marked with R, O, B, G (to stand for Red, Orange, Blue and Green suits). The second set was still 52 cards plus a joker but this used photographs of aircraft. 
Pepys saw a marketing advantage and printed rules to use the cards as a game.
The games suggested were: Pelmanism, Snap, Banker, Happy Families, Rummy, and Clock Patience.

44 cards, based on the Mickey Mouse film called 'Fun and Fancy Free'. The game also included a fold-out beanstalk in the box.
Players aim to lay sequences of cards. The cards have a a letter and number symbol on them (A2, B4, and so on). If you can complete a sequence of four cards, you win the sequence. The cards played are placed on to the Beanstalk card.

44 cards telling the story of Peter and the Wolf in the Disney film "Make Mine Music".
Players have to get rid of their cards as soon as possible whilst laying down as many sequences as they can during the game.The cards are described as four character cards and eight 'reels' of five cards each.

Players take the role of the head of an entertainment company, and in order to form an extravagant music group and compete with other players, you'll need to get hold of new talented idols! Your role also requires to find suitable working environments, hire staff, and make your idol famous. Each girl has different abilities, and you can have them work together to combine their abilities so that they can get the job done. When any player has formed a group good enough to hold a concert at the Big Dome, the game ends and the player with the most money wins.
 Each turn in the card game Idol Project, a new idol is revealed and it's up to the players to ensure that she will choose their studio and not someone else's. This is done by employing staff, purchasing equipment and becoming more famous. Having idols costs money, and the players can invest in stocks to keep the money coming.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
From the box:

It's the cool kids' game that asks... "What do these 3 have in common?"

Answer Threezer riddles and move up, bump others backwards, or get bumped yourself! The board can be full of surprises and so can the cards, but the biggest surprise will be how much fun you can have thinking in threes!

Additional note: Differs from TriBond for Kids because the board is different. The main path appears to be longer, but there are shortcuts available.

Game based on characters and incidents from the books written by Richmal Crompton.
44 cards, in 10 sets of four and 4 special cards featuring William himself and his 'sworn enemy' Violet Elizabeth. Players try to be the first to collect 2 sets.
Each player in their turn draws a card into their hand and then passes a card from their hand to the player on their left. You try to keep card sets where you have more than one card in the set (s), and have to hope you draw a matching card from the deck or you need a player on your right to pass such a card to you.

One of the first western themed games released. The game was a simple roll and move, or rather spin-and-move.

Box content:
16 circular wooden disks
a cardboard spinner with a metal arrow
board (attached to the box)

name.value: The New Game of King's Quoits

item.description:
Dexterity game similar to Tiddlywinks for four players. The objective of the game is to cause the rings to land on the pegs.

Box content:
4 bone disks, 
23 bone rings, 
2 circular felt mats, 
a textile bag 
board with 36 wooden pegs

OUTBURST the game of verbal explosions has gone electronic!

Your team gets the topic - Flowering Trees. Now yell out names to try and match the target answers. No matter how spectacular or creative your answers, you only get credit in they are on the screen! In the PLATINUM EDITION, the original OUTBURST games is sleekly packaged in this all-inclusive version along with some added features. There's double the topics as well as a built-in scorekeeper and timer. Play the traditional 10-answer game or try the 6-answer skill level for something new. PLUS the come-from-behind feature adds suspense to every game.

Press the button and watch the excitement unfold!

CONTENTS:

 Electronic OUTBURST Game
 Instructions




3AAA Batteries Required

Re-Implements:

 Outburst!

Brouhaha is a chess variant played on on a slightly expanded 8X8 board with pairs of two additional pieces added to a standard array.

The extra squares 'hang' off the edges of the board, with one on each corner and two in the middle files behind the king and queen. The extra squares which 'hang' off the corners of the standard 8x8 board are special; once the piece that occupies them moves off, they may never be entered again

The Clerics, which should be very close in value to Rooks, start in the corner squares. The basic move is that of an ordinary Bishop, but with the additional ability to leap exactly two squares horizontally or vertically.

The two Scouts start behind the king and queen and are very close in value to Knights and Bishops. The scout may step one square horizontally or vertically, or leap exactly three squares horizontally or vertically. Also, a Scout that has not moved yet this game has the added ability to move (once) like a Knight

In Play the Sign, players compete in teams or individually to be the first to rid their hand of cards. Each player starts with a randomly dealt hand of value cards and sign cards. On a turn, a player either discards a value or sign card that matches the card currently face-up on the pile or discards a number of cards for which the arithmetic calculation corresponds to the value of the face-up card.

Play the Sign can be played in single games or as a points tournament, with the player who collects the fewest points after the designated number of rounds winning the tournament.

name.value: How to Train Your Dragon: Dragon Training 101 Board Game

item.description:
From the back of the box and paraphrased from the rules:

This Dragon Training 101 Board Game is set in the mythical world of burly Vikings and wild Dragons [seen in the film How to Train Your Dragon]. As Viking teenagers living on the island of Berk, fighting dragons is a way of life Be the first Viking to Train your Dragon and reach the center training ground to WIN!

Players race to complete their 6-piece puzzle (aka "train their dragon) and reach the space in the center of the board. Players roll the die and carry out the instructions in the space on which they land. Spaces may cause players to gain or lose puzzle pieces or tokens which can protect them from losing a puzzle piece.

Contents:
1 Game Board
4 Pawns
4 Dragon Puzzles
1 Deck of Shield Cards
1 Dragon Bag
1 Die

Every year, the tribes get together for a big cookout...
 ...and everyone wants the honor of being their tribe's main course.

Who's for Dinner? is a fast and fun card game for 3-6 players, ages 12 and up. Each player plays a tribe of cannibals trying to put together the perfect combination of fire, pot and spices to score the most points. There's no player elimination as a successful "meal" means another member of that player's tribe will try to outdo their buddy in the cookpot. (In other words, players keep trying to go out and the best total score wins.) Collecting sets of items is the ultimate way to win, but there's a lot of bluffing and misdirection as action cards allow players to steal, swap or otherwise interfere with other people's cards.

Launch into the black of space to save your Home Planet!
 Space Traders is a family strategy game for 3-5 players, ages 10 and up. Players mine their Home Planets for resources, then launch trading or raiding missions to the neutral Trading Planets. Space Traders uses modular building bricks for its game pieces, allowing players to upgrade ships during the course of the game. Multiple paths to victory are possible, some players will build many ships and try to restrict access to the Trading Planets while others may build only a few ships and rely on lightening-fast raids.

Making city committee meetings fun…
 Public Transit is a light strategy game for 3-6 players, ages 12 and up. Each player is a member of the city committee responsible for planning new routes for the public transporation system. Of course, you have different priorities than the other members of the committee — wanting to make sure the route goes to certain destinations while avoiding the other member’s pet projects. You’ll lay new route markers or adjust the route on your turn, all trying to make sure each color route goes to the destinations in your hand. You might even run two routes together, to make a junction and score extra points.

User Summary:

A brief overview of the wargaming hobby including game types, scale, model collecting, painting, terrain construction, and gameplay.

The guide provides a very basic Napoleonic ruleset to get the player started on their first battle. The simple rules serve both as an introduction to general wargaming concepts (movement, fire, unit combat values, etc.) and a framework for the player to adjust and create their own rules to suite whichever time period they choose.

Published by Heritage Models, Inc., the guide was a marketing tool to help introduce new players to the wargaming hobby and their line of miniatures.

In Eco Squad players are confronted with environmental challenges in homes, cities and factories. By playing cards from their hands, they can implement solutions to these situations.

To start the game, twelve goal cards are taken randomly from the deck of 50, with four goal cards laid face up. Each goal card is labeled home, city or factory and shows two, three or four eco symbols, respectively, the symbols being air, water, energy and natural resources. Each player starts with a hand of five eco cards; most of these cards show one or two eco symbols, along with a description of what this solution represents, e.g., "Recycle used paper" shows one tree (natural resource) while "Front-loading washers" shows one water and one energy.

On a turn, a player either starts a stack of cards on the table in front of him (with at most three stacks in play), adds up to one card to each stack in play, or else discards any number of cards from hand. The player can also play one action card (of which there are five in the deck) and claim one goal card, assuming he has the needed eco symbols in a stack and the environmental solutions match the situation shown on the goal. ("Carpool lanes" are useless in providing clean air at home.)

At the end of a player's turn, he refills his hand to five cards. When a goal card is claimed, another goal card is revealed. Once the final goal card is claimed, the player with the most goals wins; in the event of a tie, the tied player who has the most eco symbols on his goal cards wins.

On September 20, 1835, the longest and bloodiest revolution in Brazil's history began. In the province of São Pedro do Rio Grande do Sul, a Riograndense Republic was proclaimed. For nearly 10 years, the troops that remained loyal to the Empire of Brazil fought epic battles against those of the new Republic!

"Farrapos" is a board game for 2 players created by Julio Trois, which has the theme of the Farroupilha Revolution. During 11 rounds each army will win the largest number of cities, adding up the maximum points possible.

"Farrapos" is a tactical game, where military strategy is very important. Each player must organize his troops, composed of tiles of infantry, cavalry and artillery. The clashes follow the style of the best wargames, using dice and tables, for the resolution of battles.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
The object of the game is to accumulate the greatest number of "sales" (points) by completing sales of insurance to prospective clients.

Universal Life was specifically designed to be played by financial security advisors of the AXA insurance company. This roll-and-move game has a predetermined course for each player to follow. Along the course, each player will encounter "clients", who will ask questions of the financial security advisor. Correctly answering the questions by providing sound advice and suggesting products will result in "sales" -- and points.

The game play is straightforward: each player, in turn, spins the wheel and moves his token the number of spaces indicated on the wheel. When a player lands on a coloured space, the player to the right must pick a card from the corresponding stack and read the question on the back of the card. If the player answers correctly, he has made a "sale" -- and gets one point.

After having completed the course, the player who has accumulated the largest number of "sales" (points) is the winner.

The object of the game is to be the first player to remove all of your disks from the game board, through a combination of luck (in rolling dice) and strategy (deciding where to move your disks).

After each player has placed his six disks on their matching "starting circles" at his side of the board, he must then move them to the opposite side of the board into the "Hexagons & Triangles" area and correctly place them on the matching hexagons.

Players must also guard themselves against encounters with other players' disks, which can disrupt or ruin their progress across the board.

-- from the game rules

Simple looking tactical game of the battle with AJAX, EXETER, ACHILLIES AND THE GRAF SPEE off the river platte early in ww2.

Heavy cardstock components, poor diecutting, but diecut units nevertheless!

There is one small strategic map in the game, and several tactical maps one for each ship involved. Each player has gunnery and torpedo markers for his ships.

The tactical maps are kept hidden from the opponent and moves are plotted with units on these maps, then translated into movement on the strategic map.

Victory conditions are simple enough with the win going to the side sinking all the enemy. If the turn limit is reached then damage and sunk british ships factor into a victory calculation.

Damage charts include hit location and various special hits. ( speed loss, gunnery loss, jammed rudders etc. )

Politically incorrect these days, in the fifties it was quite acceptable to make a game about Big Game Hunting on Safari. The animal cards are very nice though.
44 cards. Players aim to collect sets of three of the same animal. There are 6 cards of each animal per set and seven sets in all. So two sets of each animal can be 'bagged'.
There are also two 'Hunter' cards which allow a player to possibly take a set of another player that has already been 'bagged'.

This was a game based on the Disney film, Peter Pan. 44 cards, broken down to 8 sets of five plus 4 character cards - Peter Pan, Tinkerbell, Wendy and Captain Hook.
The game play is really a version of the playing card game, Sevens. The winner is the first player to use all his cards.

44 cards, depicting 7 sets of six animals plus two Hunter Cards. The object is to collect sets of three cards of the same animal.
This visits the same territory as Jungle Thrills but with differences. The main one being that you no longer bag wild animals. The Hunter card in this one is a bad card and should you have it in your hand at the end of the game, it will count against you.
Sponsored by Armand and Michaela Dennis, the most famous wild animal experts on British television.
Here players were still encouraged to shoot wild animals, but now with cameras.

"The player who most closely resembles Albert Einstein starts the game"

OVERVIEW:
A quiz game for engineers, with questions related to exact sciences only. Therefore, this is NOT a trivia game per se. The questions on the cards are designed to please both engineers, science fans and technology enthusiasts. According to BÃ¥rd Gamnes, one of the designers, the difficulty of questions are meant for "those who are about to start with their higher education".

The questions on the cards are divided into six different terms:

 Power and Forces
 Chemistry and Biology
 Computers and Gadgets
 Experiments and Explosions
 Numbers
 Engineer Mix




GAME:
After each player or team has placed their token in the middle and thus "outside" the primary playing area (much as in Pachisi), the players take turns rolling the die and moving their token onto the orbital game area, starting on one of the six rhombic fields of choice. Now and on each following turn every player may choose which way he wants to move his token on the orbital playing area. Each field the player stops on, except one that gives the player allowance to re-roll the die, is linked to a category, which another player asks him by reading from the top card from the question-card deck.

There are six fields that are obligatory to visit to collect point cards, one for each category. After that the player must try to stop on of the six rhombus shaped areas to access the middle area again, where they started. Now the player is challenged in two different and randomly chosen categories, and he needs to answer correct on both two win.

The game is for 2 - 4 teams or players.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Game inspired by the 'Find Outers' books by Enid Blyton.
44 cards. Players have to be the first to solve two mysteries, by collecting and laying out two sets of three cards.There are three 'Wild ' cards that do not belong to any set. Buster (the Find Outers dog) can earn you extra points. P.C. Goon cards lose you points and Inspector Jennings cards can cancel the effect of a Goon card.

After the Scouts got a game in 1955, now the Guides get a game.
44 cards. The game is won by the first player to play out a set of 10 cards and the First Class Badge, 11 cards in all.
A game related to Rummy type games but you don't lay down sets or sequences, you lay one card a turn, adding to the length of the sequence started by you.. Players draw a card and, if they have a 1, they must lay it in front of them. Having play a 1, they are now 'looking' for a 2, and so on. If you lay down 10 cards eventually, you only need to add a First Class Badge card (which represents an 11 in your sequence), to win the game.

Spy World is a simple game of deduction. Each player is a spy belonging to one or two secret agencies (ROCK, PAPER or SCISSOR).

The goal of a spy is to identify and reval three agents belonging to the opposite agency of his agency. Rock agents seek for Scissor agents who seek for Paper agents (who seek for Rock agents).

The game contains 9 loyalty cards and 9 cellphone cards.

Theme: 
Arena of Heroes puts the players against each other in a fighting arena as they battle to the death. The artwork is reminiscent of an arena filled with gladiators being cheered on by thousands of fans.

Game-play:
The game board consists of a 5" by 5" grid, players start in the corners, are given 10 life tokens, and dealt 5 cards each. There are 3 different types of cards in the full deck of 126 cards: black Movement Cards, red Combat Cards, and full color Item Cards. The players draw back up to a full hand of 5 cards at the beginning of each turn, allowing the player to use all their cards on their turn or hold some back to defend against attacks on the other players' turns. Each successful attack causes the defender to lose a life token.

The Center Square:
The center square of the 5" by 5" grid has special properties for both attackers and defenders. If an attacker is occupying the center square and successfully lands an attack on the defender, the defender loses 2 life tokens. If the defender is in the center square and the attacker successfully lands an attack, the attack has the choice of the defender taking the hit (and losing one life token) or knocking the attacker out of the center square and into any available adjacent square. This can setup the attacker for various combinations for dealing additional damage on a second attack on the defender by first occupying the now available center square.

Movement Cards:
Movement Cards allow the players to move their miniature one square either diagonal or orthogonal as denoted by the image on the card.

Combat Cards:
The Combat Cards are used to attack opponents either diagonal or orthogonal as denoted by the image on the card. The strength of the attack is determined by the number in the corner of the card. Combat Cards are also used to defend against attacks and are successful if the defender's card is equal to or greater than the number on the attacker's card. Combat cards can only be played against another player if their miniatures are adjacent, unless using the throwing axe (see Item Cards below).

Item Cards:
The Item Cards include various weapons, armor, and other items to modify the numbers on the Combat Cards. If a player has the two handed axe equipped (+4 to attack) and plays a Combat Card with a 7, the defender must counter the attack with an 11 or higher. If the defender had a shield equipped (+3 to defense), then only an 8 or higher is required to defend the attack. Bonuses to attack and defend do stack, but each player can only have 2 cards equipped and certain cards cannot be equipped at the same time as any others.

Goal:
Be the last player standing.

The game consists of a deck of forty-nine cards. There are twenty-two pairs of similar items; the higher priced item is several times more valuable than the lower priced one (For example: diamond rings valued at $100 and $500) plus two old trunks (three are valued at $1000, one at $200, and one at $50).

The deck is shuffled and five cards are placed face down for auction so that the players know what is up for bids but not its value. The high bidder of the open auction gets the cards and the amount spent is noted. The game continues until the deck is depleted. (There are four cards left over. I presume these cards are not auctioned but the rules don’t say.) The value of the cards won by each player is totaled and their value is subtracted from the amount spent. The player with the highest grand total is the winner.

The Deluxe Edition includes play money. Players are given $6000 in this edition and are forbidden to spend more than that.

name.value: Blitzkrieg in the West: The German Campaign in Western Europe, 1940

item.description:
Blitzkrieg in the West was designed by Joseph Miranda. It is the first in our new series of “Blitzkrieg Campaigns”, two player wargames covering the great mobile campaigns of World War II. Blitzkrieg in the West puts you in command of either the German armed forces, or the Allies, during the epic campaign for the Low Countries and France in 1940. The system uses a combination of counters, maps and cards to give players the full range of options in emerging modern warfare, with a new twist: each player has different operational capabilities, generated by cards picked in secret before start of play.

This allows for tradeoffs between additional mobile capabilities for armor, enhanced fortification effects, specialized types of air missions, and even airborne special operations. This allows for a wide range of game strategies, and ensures that every play of the game will be different. It also allows players to explore the various “what if” options of the original campaign. Players will be in the position of their historical predecessors, who can exploit new forms of warfare.

Mechanized ground unit are represented as divisions, while infantry are corps level. Headquarters can provide non-divisional support. Air units are different types of groups, differentiated by aircraft models. Special rules include shock effect, national morale, flooding lowland areas, establishing bridgeheads across rivers, open cities, and much more.

The counters are beautifully printed and die cut with full color on both sides. The game box is 9" x 12" x 3".

The game comes with extensive historical notes, providing some new insights into the climactic campaign of 1940 which changed the fate of Europe.

You and your fellows find yourselves owning plots of land in an isolated part of the countryside, halfway between two distant cities. The land is rich, travelers abound, and there is money to be had in founding a village! Will you create an economic hub, or a haven for the underprivileged? Will you foster the arts, or train mighty soldiers? When people gather and speak of your village, what tales will they tell?

Village Tale is a Print and Play Card Drafting game inspired by Satoshi Nakamura's Fairy Tale. The game takes place over four rounds of play. In each round, players are dealt six or seven cards. Each player chooses one card and passes the rest of the cards to his or her neighbor (alternating left and right each round). From the remaining cards, players choose one and pass the rest, and so on, until no cards are left to pass.

From those cards, players simultaneously play one card into one of the four districts of their village (north, south, east, and west). Any card effects are resolved. Then players play three more cards, one at a time in this fashion. Players discard their remaining cards, and go on to the next round.

After four rounds, players find out how many points their buildings are worth. Each building has a fixed value or a variable value based on the other types and locations of buildings a player has played. Whichever player has the most points wins.

In this game each player is in control of a network of nano-robots on an expanding grid playing area made up of interconnected tiles.

The goal of the game is to create all your avaliable robots before anyone else does, but along the way you can gain enhancements to make your nano-robots better at replicating by enhancing skills. Efficiently creating new robots is important, but over teching can result in your opponents getting to the end goal faster then you!

The game is played with dice representing your nano-robots, and the pips indicate the energy level it is currently at. There are several available actions you can perform on your turn, and one of them is reducing the value of the pips on a die by one and then creating a new die adjacent to it with a value of one. Players can also lay down new tiles from their hand as an action, as well as energizing certain dice which increases their pip value by a variable amount, or transfer energy around between their nano-bots.

You only have two actions available to you on each turn, so planning ahead is important! Your opponents will do things that alter your plans, but the way you lay your tiles can dictate just how affected you can be by their actions.

Unusually for Pepys at the time, they released this game in a double sized box so that it could offer two complete packs of 44 cards, one red pack and one blue pack. It was suggested in the rules that you should use one pack for 2 or 3 players, but two packs for 4 or more.
The game seems to have 'borrowed' ideas in the playing card game Bezique. Players try to win tricks, in the normal way, i.e. you must follow suit, if you cannot, then you may trump the trick. There are no trumps at the start of the game but can be introduced later. If a player can lay down a 'marriage', that is, two pairs that go together:
The Prince marries Snow White
Donald Duck marries Donna Duck
Mickey Mouse marries Minnie Mouse
Big Bad Wolf marries The Witch
The suit of such a marriage immediately becomes trumps, at least until another marriage is announced, then that suit becomes trumps.
Points are scored for marriages and winning certain cards in your tricks.

Another Pepys game that was inspired by a traditional card game (Sevens). Brilliant work by the artist.
44 cards in four suits of eleven cards, numbered 2 to 12.
Play begins when somebody lays down a 7 and places it in the centre of the table. The next player must lay down another 7, or he can add an eight or a six (of the same suit) either side of the original 7, and so on. If he cannot play a card, then he has to pass.
Players aim to play all the cards in their hand and to be the first to do so.

From the publisher's website:

Want to be a marine biologist, an astrophysicist, and a mathematician all at the same time? No prior knowledge necessary! Want to play with microscopes, chemicals, and heavy machinery? No training required! Want to make exciting new discoveries and propose revolutionary scientific theories? Welcome to The Game of Science, where you can do all this and more--in an hour or less.

The game moves forward as you hire new scientists and outfit them with the tools of their trade. You'll use your scientists and equipment to make discoveries, which give you science credits (credibility and prestige, the currency of the trade). Your scientists can also mess with the research of other players as you compete with them to accumulate the most scientific credibility. And finally, you'll use your accumulated credibility to propose theories, the key to winning the game.

But the fun isn't over yet. Now the challenge is to convince your fellow players that you can use your theories to explain something new about the world. If they believe you, they'll let you win--but if they're not convinced, one of them might steal the show!

Every game will be different, as you explore new ways to combine scientists and decide on your favorite theories. No two games will play out the same!

The Game of Science is educational as well as fun. It was developed by scientists using real scientific concepts and experiences. We wanted to share the excitement, adventure, and humor of the day-to-day life of a modern scientist.

The game developers are also active in science outreach and education. If you are a teacher interested in using this game in your classroom, we would love to hear from you to share ideas and experiences.

44 cards depicting 11 different animals or birds.
Two games are in the rules, one for a variation on Pelmanism (sometimes called Pairs) and the other for a variation of Snap (the noisy children's game).
In Pelmanism, players have to use their memory, by turning over two cards. If they match, that player keeps both cards. The idea is to win a majority of the cards.
Snap is a traditional game where cards are turned over and if two match, you must call "Snap" and if you are the first to do so, you can keep the cards. The object is to take all the cards eventually.
The illustrations aren't by an artist as they usually are for this company, but they are photographs taken at a Wildlife Park, by Phillip Wayre.
